# **Comparing Multiple Means with ANOVA**

## **Case Study #1: Results from a Diving Championship**

### **Inspecting and Charting Data**



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
data("Diving2017", package = "resampledata3")
Diving2017
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
                     Name     Country Semifinal  Final
1        CHEONG Jun Hoong    Malaysia    325.50 397.50
2                SI Yajie       China    382.80 396.00
3                REN Qian       China    367.50 391.95
4              KIM Mi Rae North Korea    346.00 385.55
5              WU Melissa   Australia    318.70 370.20
6           KIM Kuk Hyang North Korea    360.85 360.00
7         ITAHASHI Minami       Japan    313.70 357.85
8        BENFEITO Meaghan      Canada    355.15 331.40
9          PAMG Pandelela    Malaysia    322.75 322.40
10        CHAMANDY Olivia      Canada    320.55 307.15
11       PARRATTO Jessica         USA    322.75 302.35
12 MURILLO URREA Carolina    Colombia    325.75 283.35
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
Diving2017_inspect <- inspect(Diving2017)
Diving2017_inspect$categorical
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 2 × 6
  name    class  levels     n missing distribution                              
  <chr>   <chr>   <int> <int>   <int> <chr>                                     
1 Name    factor     12    12       0 " SI Yajie (8.3%) ...                    …
2 Country factor      8    12       0 "Canada (16.7%), China (16.7%) ...       …
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
Diving2017_inspect$quantitative
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 2 × 11
  name      class     min    Q1 median    Q3   max  mean    sd     n missing
* <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int>   <int>
1 Semifinal numeric  314.  322.   326.  357.  383.  338.  22.9    12       0
2 Final     numeric  283.  319.   359.  387.  398.  350.  40.0    12       0
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
Diving2017_long <- Diving2017 %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(Final, Semifinal),
    names_to = "race",
    values_to = "scores"
  )
Diving2017_long
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 24 × 4
   Name               Country     race      scores
   <fct>              <fct>       <chr>      <dbl>
 1 "CHEONG Jun Hoong" Malaysia    Final       398.
 2 "CHEONG Jun Hoong" Malaysia    Semifinal   326.
 3 " SI Yajie"        China       Final       396 
 4 " SI Yajie"        China       Semifinal   383.
 5 "REN Qian"         China       Final       392.
 6 "REN Qian"         China       Semifinal   368.
 7 "KIM Mi Rae"       North Korea Final       386.
 8 "KIM Mi Rae"       North Korea Semifinal   346 
 9 "WU Melissa"       Australia   Final       370.
10 "WU Melissa"       Australia   Semifinal   319.
# ℹ 14 more rows
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
Diving2017_long %>%
  gf_density(~scores,
    fill = ~race,
    alpha = 0.5,
    title = "Diving Scores"
  ) %>%
  gf_facet_grid(~race) %>%
  gf_fitdistr(dist = "dnorm")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



The data are not normally distributed.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
Diving2017_long %>%
  gf_col(
    fct_reorder(Name, scores) ~ scores,
    fill = ~race,
    alpha = 0.5,
    position = "dodge",
    xlab = "Scores",
    ylab = "Name",
    title = "Diving Scores"
  )
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



-   There is no immediately identifiable **trend** in score changes from one race to the other.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
Diving2017_long %>%
  gf_boxplot(
    scores ~ race,
    fill = ~race,
    alpha = 0.5,
    xlab = "Race",
    ylab = "Scores",
    title = "Diving Scores"
  )
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



-   Although the two *medians* appear to be different, the box plots overlap considerably. So one cannot visually conclude that the two sets of race timings have different *means*.

# **Comparing Multiple Means with ANOVA**

## Frog data: 



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(patchwork) # Arranging Plots
library(ggprism) # Interesting Categorical Axes
library(supernova) # Beginner-Friendly ANOVA Tables
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
frogs_orig <- read_csv("../../data/frogs.csv")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Rows: 60 Columns: 4
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
dbl (4): Frogspawn sample id, Temperature13, Temperature18, Temperature25

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
frogs_orig
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 60 × 4
   `Frogspawn sample id` Temperature13 Temperature18 Temperature25
                   <dbl>         <dbl>         <dbl>         <dbl>
 1                     1            24            NA            NA
 2                     2            NA            21            NA
 3                     3            NA            NA            18
 4                     4            26            NA            NA
 5                     5            NA            22            NA
 6                     6            NA            NA            14
 7                     7            27            NA            NA
 8                     8            NA            22            NA
 9                     9            NA            NA            15
10                    10            27            NA            NA
# ℹ 50 more rows
```


:::
:::



Our response variable is the hatching `Time`. Our explanatory variable is a *factor*, `Temperature`, with 3 levels: 13°C, 18°C and 25°C. 

### Clean the data:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
frogs_orig %>%
  pivot_longer(
    .,
    cols = starts_with("Temperature"),
    cols_vary = "fastest",
    # new in pivot_longer
    names_to = "Temp",
    values_to = "Time"
  ) %>%
  drop_na() %>%
  ##
  separate_wider_regex(
    cols = Temp,
    # knock off the unnecessary "Temperature" word
    # Just keep the digits thereafter
    patterns = c("Temperature", TempFac = "\\d+"),
    cols_remove = TRUE
  ) %>%
  # Convert Temp into TempFac, a 3-level factor
  mutate(TempFac = factor(
    x = TempFac,
    levels = c(13, 18, 25),
    labels = c("13", "18", "25")
  )) %>%
  rename("Id" = `Frogspawn sample id`) -> frogs_long
frogs_long
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 60 × 3
      Id TempFac  Time
   <dbl> <fct>   <dbl>
 1     1 13         24
 2     2 18         21
 3     3 25         18
 4     4 13         26
 5     5 18         22
 6     6 25         14
 7     7 13         27
 8     8 18         22
 9     9 25         15
10    10 13         27
# ℹ 50 more rows
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
##
frogs_long %>% count(TempFac)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 3 × 2
  TempFac     n
  <fct>   <int>
1 13         20
2 18         20
3 25         20
```


:::
:::



1.  The dataset is reshaped from wide to long format, collecting temperature data into a single `Temp` column.

2.  Missing data is dropped.

3.  The `Temp` column is cleaned to retain only the numeric values (13, 18, 25).

4.  The temperature values are converted into a factor with three levels.

5.  The sample ID column is renamed.

6.  Finally, a count is performed to see how many observations fall into each of the temperature categories (13, 18, or 25°C).

This process cleans and organizes the data, making it easier to analyze the effect of temperature on the frogs' data.

### Data Visualizations:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
gf_histogram(~Time,
  fill = ~TempFac,
  data = frogs_long, alpha = 0.5
) %>%
  gf_vline(xintercept = ~ mean(Time)) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Histograms of Hatching Time Distributions vs Temperature",
    x = "Hatching Time", y = "Count"
  ) %>%
  gf_text(7 ~ (mean(Time) + 2),
    label = "Overall Mean"
  ) %>%
  gf_refine(guides(fill = guide_legend(title = "Temperature level (°C)")))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Temprature and hatching time seem to have a +ve corelation.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
gf_boxplot(
  data = frogs_long,
  Time ~ TempFac,
  fill = ~TempFac,
  alpha = 0.5
) %>%
  gf_vline(xintercept = ~ mean(Time)) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Boxplots of Hatching Time Distributions vs Temperature",
    x = "Temperature", y = "Hatching Time",
    caption = "Using ggprism"
  ) %>%
  gf_refine(
    scale_x_discrete(guide = "prism_bracket"),
    guides(fill = guide_legend(title = "Temperature level (°C)"))
  )
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Warning: The S3 guide system was deprecated in ggplot2 3.5.0.
ℹ It has been replaced by a ggproto system that can be extended.
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Temperature seems to have a huge effect of hatching time

## **ANOVA**

A statistical test for 3 or more means:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
frogs_anova <- aov(Time ~ TempFac, data = frogs_long)
```
:::



ErrorBar plot



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
supernova::pairwise(frogs_anova,
  correction = "Bonferroni", # Try "Tukey"
  alpha = 0.05, # 95% CI calculation
  var_equal = TRUE, # We'll see
  plot = TRUE
)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672}
:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```

```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
── Pairwise t-tests with Bonferroni correction ─────────────────────────────────
```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Model: Time ~ TempFac
```


:::


::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
TempFac
```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Levels: 3
```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Family-wise error-rate: 0.049
```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

  group_1 group_2    diff pooled_se       t    df   lower  upper p_adj
  <chr>   <chr>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> <int>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>
1 18      13       -5.300     0.257 -20.608    57  -5.861 -4.739 .0000
2 25      13      -10.100     0.257 -39.272    57 -10.661 -9.539 .0000
3 25      18       -4.800     0.257 -18.664    57  -5.361 -4.239 .0000
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
supernova::pairwise(frogs_anova,
  correction = "Tukey",
  alpha = 0.05, # 95% CI calculation
  var_equal = TRUE, # We'll see
  plot = TRUE
)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672}
:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```

```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
── Tukey's Honestly Significant Differences ────────────────────────────────────
```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Model: Time ~ TempFac
```


:::


::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
TempFac
```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Levels: 3
```


:::

```
Family-wise error-rate: 0.05
```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

  group_1 group_2    diff pooled_se       q    df   lower  upper p_adj
  <chr>   <chr>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> <int>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>
1 18      13       -5.300     0.257 -20.608    57  -6.175 -4.425 .0000
2 25      13      -10.100     0.257 -39.272    57 -10.975 -9.225 .0000
3 25      18       -4.800     0.257 -18.664    57  -5.675 -3.925 .0000
```


:::
:::



The black points: Estimate difference in means of the hatching time i.e. differences in mean pair vise.

## Proportions:

CLT for proportions
 1. sample proportion = population propotion
 2. only go ahead with a sample if it has atleast 10 of the "minority"
 
 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
data(yrbss, package = "openintro")
yrbss
```
